As reported by the Puri Collector, Jena failed to discharge his assigned duties during distribution of cash assistance of Rs 1,000 to ration card holders under National Food Security Act (NFSA) and State Food Security Scheme (SFSS) on April 10 against the assigned date on April 2.

“The delinquent has failed to perform his assigned duties by not adhering to the Government order on social distancing during distribution of financial assistance to ration card holders in Wards-6 and 7 of Nimapara NAC,” the order stated.

During the period of suspension, Jena’s headquarters will be the office of the Project Director, District Urban Development Agency, Puri and he shall not leave the headquarters without obtaining prior permission of the competent authority.

Title: Government issues advisory on use of hydroxychloroquine
Article:
The increase in the number of COVID-19 positive cases in the State has created panic in the State. And the situation has drawn people’s attention to the hydroxychloroquine drug.

But how advisable is the use of this medicine?

In a bid bust the myths surrounding COVID-19, the Health and Family Welfare Department on Thursday issued an advisory regarding usage of COVID-19 medicines.

The advisory said:

Hydroxychloroquine is a prescription medicine.

People, under no circumstances, should consume any medicine without proper health checkup or prescription.

Hydroxychloroquine is prescribed only for asymptomatic healthcare workers, household contacts and laboratory confirmed cases.

In a combination with azithromycin, hydroxychloroquine is an off-label indication in patients with severe disease and who require ICU attention.

Anyone who’s making its illegal sale will attract legal action under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.

Title: ‘Provide rice, pulses to needy not under NFSA, SFSS'
Article:
Leader of Opposition (LoP) in State Assembly Pradipta Naik on Thursday urged Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik for free distribution of rice and pulses to all the needy families who are not covered under the National Food Security Act (NFSA) and the State Food Security Scheme (SFSS).

In a letter to the Chief Minister, Naik noted that many of the non-NFSA and non-SFSS beneficiaries are facing difficulties in meeting their daily needs due to the ongoing COVID-19 lockdown period.

He urged the CM to provide free rice and pulses under PDS to all those households who have no ration cards.

“The Centre has made certain relaxation in rules for use of State Disaster Response Fund (SDRF) and District Mineral Foundation (DMF) Fund to fight COVID-19 in the country. I request you to make arrangement by using these funds to provide free rice and pulses to those poor families, who are yet to avail ration cards,” wrote the LoP.

He also requested to put the list of non-NFSA and non-SFSS beneficiaries at panchayat offices for necessary use.

Title: 120 Battalion holds blood donation camp
Article:
Due to COVID-19-induced lockdown restrictions, blood banks in the State, especially in Bhubaneswar, are now facing shortage of blood as blood donations camps are not being held.

Many patients, including thalassemia, are facing a lot of inconvenience for the shortage of blood.

Rising to the occasion, the 120 Infantry Battalion (TA) organised a blood donation camp in its premises here on Tuesday.

The Blood Bank of the Bhubaneswar Municipality Corporation Hospital collected blood. The Red Cross, Commissionerate Police Branch facilitated in organising the camp. Dr KK Sarkar of blood bank was present.

Commanding Officer Colonel DD Swain and other officers donated blood first. Then, soldiers and their family members donated. A total of 50 units of blood were collected.

All safety precautions against COVID-19 pandemic were strictly observed.

The tailoring unit of the "Family Welfare Organisation" of the battalion is making thousands of reusable cloth masks which are being distributed amongst the poor and needy persons.

The State administration has appreciated this humanitarian efforts of the 120 Infantry Battalion (TA) during hours of crisis.

Title: Two Punjab jails made quarantine units
Article:
As a preventive measure to keep further spread of corona virus under check, Punjab Jails Minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa on Thursday announced that Barnala and Patti Jails will be made quarantine centres with immediate effect. As many 412 inmates, lodged in these jails, have already been shifted in other jails of the state, he said.

“Any new inmate would be sent to these jails for quarantine after proper medical examination. This preventive step had been taken to avoid any possible danger of corona virus in the jails of the State,” said Randhawa, adding that any symptomatic inmate would only be sent to Barnala and Patti sub jails for quarantine.

Any new such inmate would be sent to these quarantine jails after his thorough examination as per the health protocol and advisories, he added.

COVID SUSPECT FLEE FROM ISOLATION WARD, CAUGHT

A Covid-19 suspect, who had fled from the isolation ward of a hospital in Punjab’s Hoshiarpur district, was caught by police on Thursday. Yusuf Khan’s samples had been sent for testing, and he was under quarantine when he fled from the hospital on Wednesday night, creating scare among the people in the district and surrounding areas. He was a resident of Nagrota in Himachal Pradesh. Acting swiftly, the Punjab Police arrested the 40-year-old man from Chabbewal town in Hoshiarpur the next day. Hoshiarpur Civil Hospital Senior Medical Officer (SMO) Dr Jaswinder Singh said that Khan was referred from Dasuya to Hoshiarpur Civil Hospital. “We sent his samples for checking on Tuesday. He fled from the sample collection room by breaking a plywood piece which was fitted in the window against the space meant for AC,” he said.

8620 COPS, 6483 VOLUNTEERS ON DUTY IN VILLAGES, MANDIS

As many as 8620 Punjab Police personnel, along with 6483 volunteers, are maintaining a round-the-clock vigil at the mandis and in villages to ensure smooth procurement operations amid the Covid-19 crisis, with stringent guidelines for their own protection and for strict enforcement of health and sanitation protocols as well as social distancing measures at all procurement centres. DGP Dinkar Gupta said that as part of two-pronged strategy, the frontline police personnel on duty at mandis have been equipped to protect farmers and others coming to these centres, while also ensuring their own protection.

All police personnel have been provided with face masks, gloves, hand sanitizers etc and also briefed about their proper usage. Police personnel having health issues, especially those relating to heart and respiratory issues, are not deployed for frontline duty. They have also been tasked with maintaining social distancing at procurement centres, and checking the passes issued to farmers and arhtiyas to avoid crowding and congestion in the mandis.

PUNJAB LAUNCHES SPECIAL COVID HELPLINE FOR ADVICE

To effectively address and resolve medical and stress related issues during lockdown, Punjab Government has launched a special helpline — 1800-180-4104 — for citizens to connect with a network of senior doctors over tele-conference and get medical advice on Covid-19 and other related concerns. State Covid Control Room Team member Ravi Bhagat said that a panel of expert doctors have been duly trained about the platform, its protocol and functionalities to counsel anxiety related issues in the wake of the lockdown.

The focus would be to identify and prioritize cases for emergency medical attention with a wider technological reach for people from less privileged sections, Bhagat said underlining the need to not overwhelm our health apparatus. “This counseling shall also help identify cases for isolation, home quarantine and those who require medical attention. The cases shall be notified to the government for further tracking and action,” he said adding that this feature has also been added to COVA Punjab mobile application available on Android PlayStore and IOS AppStore.

Title: After being declared hotspot, UT to follow two new protocols
Article:
With Chandigarh being declared as Covid-19 hotspot (red zone) by the Central Government, the UT Administration will now follow two new protocols including testing all suspect cases and stringent measures to restrict unnecessary movement at the city’s borders.

Chandigarh, which is a joint capital of Punjab and Haryana, has been declared as Covid-19 (Coronavirus) hotspot, in a list of 170 such districts released by the Central Government.

The city has so far recorded 21 positive Coronavirus cases, out of which nine have already recovered and no death has been reported till Thursday evening. No new positive case has been reported in the past four days.

While 1738 were put in home quarantine as a precautionary measure, 1328 have completed the quarantine period.

UT Home-cum-Health Secretary Arun Kumar Gupta told The Pioneer, “Since the city has been declared a Coronavirus hotspot by the Central Government, the Administration would be following two additional protocols. Now, testing of all suspect cases would be done and strict measures will be taken to restrict movement at city’s border.”

Elaborating, Gupta said, “Earlier, testing of symptomatic cases, asymptomatic direct contacts and high-risk contacts of a confirmed case were done. Now, testing of all suspect cases will be done. If anyone is reporting influenza like illness (ILI) symptoms (fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose), that person will be tested for Coronavirus within 3-4 days in the city. Though the protocol says seven days, we have decided to conduct test in such cases in 3-4 days.”

He said, “The entire city is now a containment zone, so stringent measures would be taken at city’s borders to restrict movement. We have given 50 thermal scanning devices to the UT Police to ensure thermal screening at all the city’s border areas. Besides, movement of individuals at inter-state borders will be allowed only for essential services and urgent reasons.”

“Another protocol is to conduct door to door survey for Coronavirus symptoms, which had already begun in Chandigarh. 6.85 lakh city’s population has been covered through door to door survey and screening till now,” Gupta said.

“During the ongoing survey, 3 cases were found to have Coronavirus symptoms but they have been tested negative for the disease,” he added.

A nationwide lockdown had begun from March 25 (12 am) while curfew was imposed in Chandigarh on March 24 (12 am) to ensure social distancing and combat the spread of Coronavirus.

The UT Administration has already approached Punjab and Haryana Governments to run their offices in Chandigarh with minimal staff, since the entire city has been declared as hotspot district and is under curfew. Apart from this, the UT Director General of Police has been directed to intensify checking in borders and to ensure that only the pass-holders and authorized persons are allowed to enter the capital city.

Notably, as per Centre’s guidelines, restrictions will continue to apply on Covid-19 hotspots for the next 28 days and there will be no relaxations after April 20, which will be applicable to non-hotspots in the country. A district, however, could move from the red to the green zone if it does not report any case for 28 days, and vice-versa.

Title: Ludhiana Administration halts home delivery of food
Article:
After a Delhi pizza delivery boy was tested positive for coronavirus and 72 families quarantined, Ludhiana Administration on Thursday decided to bring to a halt all home delivery services of food establishments to curb the spread of coronavirus.

Ludhiana Deputy Commissioner and District Magistrate Pradeep Agarwal said: “The permissions regarding food preparation establishments given earlier only for home delivery, were on an experimental basis and for a limited duration of time.”

“Now, in an alarming situation arising due to coronavirus across the country and the risks attached to food contamination, it has been decided to stop all the operations of food establishments till further orders,” he added.

Meanwhile, all the permissions stood cancelled with immediate effect, and any establishment, if found providing home delivery, would be held responsible for violating the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, and Disaster Management Act,2005.

Title: 1 death, 11 new cases, Punjab stands at 197
Article:
Punjab on Thursday reported another death along with 11 new coronavirus cases, taking the state’s death toll to 14 and total confirmed cases to 197.

Among the 14 fresh cases, maximum six have been reported from Jalandhar followed by three from Patiala, and two from Pathankot. However, Gurdaspur’s first and the only case, 60-year-old Sansar Singh from Bhaini Passwal village, died at Amritsar’s Government Medical College and Hospital.

Sansar Singh had recently attended the cremation of an ex-army subedar, who was his relative. The man had later tested positive for coronavirus and died in Jalandhar.

Later, Sanasr Singh too showed symptoms of the disease, following which he visited a private hospital in BSF Chowk in Gurdaspur, where the hospital staff asked him to get admitted to the Gurdaspur civil hospital. After a preliminary check-up, he was referred to Amritsar.

Senior Superintendent of Police Swarandeep Singh said that the village and its adjoining hamlets have been declared as containment zones, and the movement will be severely restricted. Out of 105 suspected cases in Gurdaspur district, one has tested positive while 91 have tested negative and the reports of 13 are pending, said Gurdaspur Deputy Commissioner Mohammad Ishfaq.

The state’s Special Chief Secretary Karan Bir Singh Sidhu tweeted, “Sansar Singh, the first Covid-19 patient from Gurdaspur district, has expired at GNDH Amritsar. His cremation will be held in Gurdaspur today.” The patient was admitted to a private hospital in Gurdaspur on April 9 after he complained of increased sugar level and problem in breathing. The doctors advised him to undergo treatment at Fortis Hospital, Amritsar, but he preferred the Civil Hospital in Gurdaspur.

It has been learnt that the lady doctor who attended to him in the private hospital has been quarantined for 14 days. The Health Department has also traced 46 close contacts of the deceased, and their samples have been sent to Government Medical College (GMC), Amritsar, and their reports are awaited. Meanwhile, Jalandhar on Thursday reported six new coronavirus cases, taking the total in the district to 31.

While five cases are the contacts of the earlier positive patients, one is the patient of Severe Acute Respiratory Illness.

The husband of the deceased Shahkot woman, who had tested positive on Sunday, also tested positive for the disease. As many 66 people had attended her cremation.

Title: 9 members of family test positive for Covid-19 in Panchkula
Article:
Nine members of a family from Panchkula near Chandigarh have tested positive for coronavirus, officials said. A 44-year-old woman, her husband and seven other members of their family, who reside in two houses in Sector 15, have tested positive.

The woman developed some symptoms on April 6, he said, adding later she went to a private hospital in Panchkula where he doctor took an X-ray and found a spot on her lung and administered some antibiotics.However, the woman reported to Panchkula civil hospital on April 12 after which her samples were collected which came positive. Subsequently, the samples of other members of her family were also taken and eight more were found positive, he said.

Title: 17 city residents who came in contact with Pkl family home quarantined
Article:
With nine members of a family from neighboring Panchkula districts in Haryana tested positive for Coronavirus, the Chandigarh Administration on Thursday swung into action for contact tracing exercise and identified 17 people in Sector 41 here.

“Till evening, 17 family contacts living as a joint family in Sector 41 here were traced and put under home quarantine. Out of these two are primary contacts of the Panchkula positive cases,” said an official spokesman.

Both these primary contacts have been sampled for Covid-19 at GMSH-16 on Thursday and their results are awaited, the spokesman said.

Nine members of a family from Sector 15 Panchkula were tested positive for Coronavirus, thus taking the district total to 14 till Thursday evening.

Meanwhile, no fresh case of coronavirus has been reported in the city on Thursday. Chandigarh, which is listed as Coronavirus hotspots, has so far reported 21 positive Covid-19 cases, out of which nine have already recovered.

A total of 227 samples have been tested so far while the report of two was awaited till the filing of this report.

As a precautionary measure, 1738 people have been put in home quarantine, out of which 1328 have completed the quarantine period till now.

The first positive case of COVID-19 in the city was reported on March 19.

Title: No new patient in U’khand for second consecutive day
Article:
No new patient of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) was reported for second consecutive day in Uttarakhand on Thursday. The State has so far reported 37 cases of the pandemic which has taken more than 1.36 lakh lives in the world and derailed the global economy.

However in comparison to other parts of the country, the outbreak of the disease appears to be controlled so far with 37 patients. Out of them, nine patients have recovered completely and have been discharged from the hospitals.

The additional secretary, medical health and family welfare department, Yugal Kishore Pant said that informed that reports of 186 suspected patients were received by the department on Thursday and all of them were found negative for the disease.

He said that reports of 346 samples are still awaited. The authorities have so far taken swab samples of 2593 suspected patients for COVID-19 test. On Thursday, samples of 161 suspected patients were taken and sent to the lab for test.

The health department collected 84 samples from Haridwar district on the day while 26 samples were collected from Dehradun. The authorities collected 16 samples each from Udham Singh Nagar and Nainital districts.

A total of 1,898 people are under institutional quarantine while 450 suspected patients in hospital isolation.

The authorities have kept 62,425 people are in home quarantine in different parts of the state.

In the State, Dehradun district with 18 cases so far is at the top of the table and as per the central government guidelines is a hot spot district and kept in red zone.

The districts of Chamoli, Rudraprayag, Tehri, Uttarkashi, Champawat, Bageshwar and Pithoragarh have so far reported no case of the disease while Nainital and Haridwar districts have so far reported eight and five cases respectively.

In Udham Singh Nagar four patients have so far been found while one patient each has been reported from Pauri and Almora districts.

Title: CM holds meet with Ministers, officials to decide lockdown conditions
Article:
Various decisions were taken in a meeting chaired by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat with his cabinet colleagues and senior bureaucrats on Thursday. The guidelines issued on Wednesday by the Government of India for containment of COVID-19 were discussed and decisions regarding the extended lockdown were taken accordingly for the state.

Informing about the decisions, cabinet minister and state government spokesman Madan Kaushik said that all units in industrial estates will be allowed to function after April 20. However, they will have to seek permission from the district magistrate and strictly follow Central Government guidelines in this regard. Further, marriages will be allowed in the state provided the function takes place inside a home and only five persons from one side will be permitted to attend the function.

It will be mandatory to wear a mask in all public places and offices. It will be mandatory for anyone travelling from one place to another, to follow directions issued by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare for maintaining social distancing in public place, work place and in traffic. More than five persons congregating in any public place will remain prohibited. Further, the permission of the district magistrate will be needed for any marriage or funeral. A penalty will be imposed on anyone spitting in public place.

The sale of liquor, gutka and tobacco will remain prohibited along with spitting in public place. Every workplace should have proper temperature screening facility and sanitiser at the proper place.

There should be at least one hour gap between shifts and during meals too the staff should maintain social distancing. Personnel aged above 65 years and those who have children aged below five years will be encouraged to work from home. All governmental and non governmental personnel and general public will be motivated to use the Aarogya Setu application.

At construction sites, the surface will have to be cleaned consistently and hand washing arrangements will be made for the labourers. Shifts should not overlap and social distancing must be ensuring during meals.

Further, the nearby area must be kept clean. When it comes to industries, all units in rural areas and in industrial estates will be allowed to operate after securing formal permission from the district magistrate.

Precautions against COVID-19 as directed by the Government of India will have to be strictly followed. Since there are 64,129 MSMEs and 327 industries registered in the state, the industry department has set up a portal for online applications.

All industrial units applying for permission to operate will also have to provide full details of arrangements made in accordance with COVID-19 standard operating procedures and transportation of labourers. After ensuring compliance of the mandatory requirements, permission will be granted by the district magistrate.

Title: Every house to be screened in Hry
Article:
Stating that the areas which have been declared as Containment Zones in Haryana have been completely sealed, Haryana Health Minister Anil Vij on Thursday said that to eradicate Covid-19, Health Department teams will visit every house in the State for the screening of each person.

Interacting with media persons after a review meeting regarding the preparedness for Covid-19 with Home, Health and Family Welfare, Medical Education and Research, and Urban Local Bodies Departments in Chandigarh, he said these four departments are fighting on the forefront against Covid-19 in the State and the officers and employees of these departments have done excellent work in making the lockdown-1 a success. He said today there are a total of 149 active cases in Haryana.

Vij said that advisories are being issued from time to time by the Central Government regarding Covid-19 patients and these advisories are being implemented in Haryana as well. In this series, the Containment Zone and Buffer Zone have been created, under which the definitions of Containment Zone and Buffer Zone are different in rural and urban areas.

He said that the officers have been directed that sanitization works should be carried out daily in the Containment Zone and sanitization will be done under the second phase in the entire state as well.

The Minister said that the bank premises, mandis, markets, grocery stores, chemist shops as well as ration depots have been directed to maintain social distancing in their establishments and if any establishment fails to maintain the same then they will not be allowed to open or operate.

He said that a letter has been written to the Indian Medical Association (IMA) that in view of the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic, they should ask private doctors to open their private clinic so that the general public can be treated for other diseases and problems. Similarly, he said that the Health Department has been directed to keep retired doctors on contract for one year so that the Covid-19 pandemic can be dealt with properly. He said that so far 197 doctors have joined their duty and it has been decided to give joining letters to 58 doctors on the waiting list.

Vij informed that nine special Covid Hospitals equipped with ICUs, ventilators and other equipment have been set up in Haryana in which teams of best doctors have been appointed. He said that Covid-19 patients will only be kept in Covid Hospital and they will not be kept in any other general hospital. Apart from this, he informed that 411 mobile dispensaries have also been started in Haryana which will help in treating other diseases.

In response to a question, Vij said that the lockdown will be strictly enforced and action will also be taken against the violators under the necessary laws. He said that the police officers have been directed to strictly implement the lockdown and Containment Zone should be properly monitored.

Similarly, in response to another question, he said that Haryana was the first state in the country where the Epidemic Act was implemented, under which it was directed to file an FIR against the negligent private doctor for not bringing the case of the Covid-19 positive Sector-15, Panchkula resident to the notice of the Civil Surgeon as it is the duty of private doctors to give the information about the Covid-19 patients to the concerned officers and administration.

Title: PUNJAB IN SECOND STAGE: HEALTH MINISTER
Article:
Punjab Health and Family Welfare Minister Balbir Singh Sidhu on Thursday claimed that as of now, the State is in the second stage of local transmission.

His assertion assumes significance as the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh has already expressed his apprehensions of the State entering into the stage of community transmission. Notably, out of 197 cases, the State has more than two dozen cases where source of infection is untraced.

“Now, Punjab is in second stage and to deal with unprecedented circumstances, the frontline teams of health department is constantly working on war footing to trace all the contacts of affected patient which is the single way to curb the spread of this highly contagious disease,” said Sidhu.

He said that the State Government is well prepared to combat the corona virus pandemic and Punjab would set an example in fight against COVID-19.

Underlining the present status of Punjab, Sidhu said that 29 persons have been declared cured. “Most of the cases are related to foreign travel background or their contacts. The teams of Health Department are continuously doing the door-to-door screening in the affected areas to identify the suspected patients,” he said.

Highlighting the Government’s preparedness to deal the corona virus patient, the Minister said that for care of COVID-19 patients, nearly 5186 isolation beds have been identified in Government and Private Health facilities with about 480 ventilators and 1101 ICU beds available for the same.

To take care of COVID patients who have very mild symptoms, COVID Care Isolation Centers have been planned each having a capacity of 500-1000 beds. All critical COVID patients will go to three Government Medical Colleges and two private Medical Colleges.

At the same time, he assured that there is adequate supply of PPE kits, N95 masks and triple layer masks which is being provided to all hospitals and Government Medical Colleges.

IMPLEMENTING CONTAINMENT PLAN WHERE CLUSTER OF CASES REPORTED

The Minister said that Punjab’s four districts — SAS Nagar, SBS Nagar, Jalandhar and Pathankot — have been declared as hotspots by the Central Government based on the number of cases, that is where more than 15 cases of COVID-19 have been reported so far.

Revealing about containment plan, Sidhu said that wherever there is clustering of cases, the whole area within a radius of three kilometers around the positive patients is covered. “The area is sealed and no entry or exit of people is allowed. Surveillance is done for searching symptomatic persons and testing,” he said.

If anyone found positive for COVID-19, they are immediately rushed to isolation centers. All the goods needed by population are provided at doorsteps,” he said.

Sidhu said that similar strategy has been implementing in 24 hotspots of nine districts, already identified by the State Government, while special attention is being paid at SAS Nagar and Jalandhar districts where, till date, higher number of cases has been reported.

“Besides taking samples of contacts of affected patients, 1000 rapid test kits have been given to both districts to throttle the process of testing so that this outbreak can be locked in the specific areas and all the new confirmed cases to be put under treatment as earliest,” he said.

He added that all roads connected to hotspots area has been closed with the help of Police department and curfew restrictions are strictly being implemented to break the spread.

SUCCEEDED IN BREAKING CHAIN IN WORST HIT DISTRICT

Sidhu said that as of today, “we have one of the foremost example of SBS Nagar (Nawanshahr) where the State Government has successfully break the chain of corona virus and the number of patients freeze at 19 since March 26”.

Of the 19 patients, 17 patients have been cured, while one patient Baldev Singh died, and “we hope one remaining patient will also be recovered soon”.

The district reported its first case on March 18, that too after 70-year-old Baldev Singh died due to cardiac arrest and tested positive a day after. The first coronavirus casualty, Baldev Singh infected 27 people, including 18 from Nawanshahr alone.

EXPERTS PANEL FORMED FOR CHECKING MORTALITY RATE

The Minister said that for better clinical management of sick patients, and check mortality rates, a committee of experts has also been constituted which will support treating doctors in taking decision for management of patients.

Regular webinars are being conducted for doctors involved in treatment of COVID-19 patients to bring them up to date regarding latest treatment guidelines, he said.

Title: Punjab TEITD starts online classes for ITI students
Article:
Punjab Technical Education and Industrial Training Department has started the online classes to provide training to the students of the Industrial Training Institutes of the State. The e-Learning content of theoretical subjects has been identified for 34 trades by constituting the committees of the Principals and Instructors, said the state Principal Secretary (Technical Education and Industrial Training) Anurag Verma on Thursday.

As per the directions of Technical Education Minister Charanjit Singh Channi, the Department has taken this initiative so that the studies of the students do not suffer and also to safeguard their academic interests, he said.

Verma said that e-Learning material has been identified from various sites such as Bharat Skills, National Instructional Media Institute (NIMI), YouTube etc. The e-Learning material has been arranged week wise as per the syllabus prescribed by NCVT, Director General of Training, Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship, Government of India.

“The e-Learning material would be sent to the trainees one day before till 4 pm via Whatsapp. Next day from 10.30 am to 4 pm, the instructors would take online class of 40 to 60 minutes and give assignments to the trainees.

The Assignments are to be submitted back till 6 pm at Whatsapp. A test would also be conducted on weekend. Engineering drawing and workshop calculation and science classes would be conducted every day at 3 pm for students of engineering trades,” said Verma.

Maintaining that he himself had attended online classes in four ITIs of Bhatinda, Ludhiana, Fatehgarh Churian and Patiala, Berma said: “Although a few difficulties are being faced in implementation of this system as of now, but the trainees and trainers are very enthusiastic about this online system…The process would be improved constantly by taking regular feedback from all stakeholders.”

Title: Covid-19 testing to be increased in State’: HP CM
Article:
Himachal Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Thursday said that samples of coronavirus tests would be increased in the State and directed that tests of all persons of Tablighi Jamat and their contacts for coronavirus should be completed at the earliest.

Reviewing the situation with senior officers of the State in the wake of coronavirus pandemic, he said rapid testing kits would be made available to the State soon which would increase the pace of testing. He said that these testing kits would also be helpful in testing the people of Himachal Pradesh entering the State in case of emergent situations.

Thakur said screening centres would be established at all the interstate barriers at entry points and all the persons entering the State with permits issued by the authorities of other States would be tested with rapid diagnostic kits. He said that temporary quarantine centres with at least 15-20 beds would be established near these centres.

The Chief Minister said that any person found positive would be shifted to these quarantine centres and would not be allowed to travel inside the State and would further be confirmed for coronavirus with RT-PCR test. He said that any movement from designated hotspots would also be monitored and persons with ILI etc. would be tested with rapid diagnostic kits for identification of any Covid-19 positive

cases.

Thakur said State Government has entrusted the responsibility to representatives of PRIs to keep strict vigil on persons who have come to their areas from outside or even within the state. He said that State Government would not even hesitate to take action against the panchayat pradhans who conceal information regarding the arrival of the outsiders.

The Chief Minister stressed the need of adequate stock of essential commodities in open markets and depots of Civil Supplies Corporation to facilitate the people.

He said social distancing must be ensured amongst the people during relaxation of curfew which will break the chain of coronavirus. He directed the officers that trucks carrying essential commodities and other materials from other states should also be sanitized at the borders of the state along-with its drivers and conductors.

Thakur said that the State Government was concerned about the people of Himachal Pradesh stranded outside the state. The Government is in constant touch with these people and the respective State Governments have been requested to ensure their proper care. He urged such people to remain wherever they are as the Government would ensure their early return as soon as the situation normalizes.

Asking the officers to explore possibilities of establishing contacts between the farmers and the buyers so that they could sell their produce at remunerative prices, he said that smooth transportation of horticulture produce and inputs must also be

ensured.

Education Minister Suresh Bhardwaj, Chief Secretary Anil Khachi, Director General of Police S.R. Mardi, Additional Chief Secretary Manoj Kumar and R.D. Dhiman, Principal Secretaries J.C. Sharma and Onkar Sharma and Sanjay Kundu also attended the meeting.

Title: Social distancing norms violated by Punjab Min
Article:
In an apparent zeal to inspect the ongoing wheat procurement process and score brownie points, Punjab Minister and lawmakers on Thursday virtually ended up violating the lockdown and social distancing norms.

Throwing to winds the social distancing norms, the state’s Food and Civil Supplies Minister Bharat Bhushan Ashu, accompanied by Congress’ Fatehgarh Sahib MP Amar Singh, and Khanna MLA Gurkirat Singh Kotli, along with more than two dozens men visited Khanna grain market not only to inspect the ongoing procurement process, but also to get themselves clicked.

As per the curfew restrictions, the State Government has prohibited the gathering of more than 20 people at one place. Notably, Punjab Police has also been registering cases against those who are violating the ban order regarding restrictions on gathering.

The violation of orders and social distancing rule by those in power comes at a time when the state government has made special arrangements across 3000 grain markets to maintain safe distance to check the spread of deadly virus.

Ashu, the minister in-charge, take stock of the ongoing process at state’s biggest grain market at Khanna. And in the process, he and many others neglected the social distancing. Besides the dignitaries, Ashu’s gunmen also accompanied him.

Even though they all have been seen wearing face masks, they were standing close to each other, posing for the shutterbugs.

In an irony of sorts, Ashu, while talking with the media later on, said that the social distancing norms are being enforced in the mandis in accordance with which box measuring 30 feet x 30 feet have been marked at two meters distance.

Later, Ashu also visited Mullanpur grain market along with Congress’ Ludhiana MP Ravneet Singh Bittu, senior Congress leader Capt Sandeep Singh Sandhu, and several others — flouting social distancing norms.

In another similar incident, Congress MLA from Shutrana Nirmal Singh, review the arrangement at Patran anaj mandi along with several others.

The senior government officials have expressed surprise over the incident and described it as “sad”. But it is still unclear whether the matter has been brought to the Chief Minister’s notice.

Title: IN BRIEF
Article:
Himachal Governor issues directions

Shimla: Himachal Director, Women and Child Development Kritika Kulaihari called on Governor Bandaru Dattatraya at Raj Bhavan and apprised him about various steps taken by the department during the lockdown. The Governor advised the department to give instruction to Anganwadi Workers to sensitize the people in rural areas for the preparation of homemade masks. These workers should also work in coordination with the Health Department and provide information in detail about the movement of people. Self-help groups should also be motivated in this direction by the department, he added. He asked to provide ration to migrant labourers in coordination with police, food supply and Health Departments.

M3MF contributes Rs 1 crore to Hry CMRF

Chandigarh: M3M Foundation, the philanthropic arm of realty developer M3M Group has donated Rs 1crore to the Chief Minister's Relief Fund in Haryana. The company has been actively supporting construction workers and daily wage earners with food and essentials requirements. Payal Kanodia, Trustee, M3M Foundation said, “We are going through extraordinary times, we never thought of. We all need to rise to the occasion and fight this precarious situation together. The government is doing a commendable job in containing the current crisis and it becomes imperative that we stand with them at this moment.”

VC insists on confidence building measures

Chandigarh: Prof. Raj Kumar, Vice Chancellor, Panjab University chaired the second round of online meeting of the 38 chairpersons, directors and coordinators of different departments, institutes and centres including regional centres of PU at Ludhiana, Hoshiarpur and Muktsar. PU VC had one to one interaction with the heads to know about the online academic activities going on and also enquired about the syllabus covered till now. He appreciated the concerted efforts of the teaching fraternity of the varsity towards promoting the academic interests of the students. Prof. Raj Kumar urged all to ensure connecting of the faculty with the students through possible online options for confidence building during testing times.

Title: Cops manning Punjab mandis to ensure social distancing
Article:
As many 8,620 police personnel and 6,483 volunteers are maintaining a round-the-clock vigil at the grain markets to ensure social distancing and smooth procurement of wheat in Punjab.

Director General of Police Dinkar Gupta said the frontline police personnel on duty at the mandis have been equipped to protect the farmers and others coming to these centres, while also ensuring their own protection. All police personnel have been provided with face masks, gloves, hand sanitizers, etc, and also briefed about their proper usage. Police personnel having health issues, especially those relating to heart and respiration, are not deployed for frontline duty.

To ensure proper social distancing, public address systems are being used for effective dissemination of guidelines and instructions so that physical proximity is avoided at

the procurement centres, which are being regularly sanitised.

The police personnel deployed in various mandis have been asked to ensure checking at all entry/exit points, traffic flow and de-congestion of roads leading up to the mandi and purchase centres, besides ensuring law and order and proper flow of people and vehicular movement.

They have also been tasked with maintaining social distancing at procurement centres, and checking the passes issued to farmers and ''arthiyas'' (commission agents) to avoid crowding and congestion in the mandis.

Gupta said the police personnel have also been directed to ensure that combine harvesters do not operate at night after 7 pm, and to allow only one trolley with one person having a valid coupon at the entry point of the village to go to the mandi.

Elaborating on the role of volunteers during harvesting/procurement, Gupta said they had been given the task of ensuring social distancing in mandis, so as to make people, especially the farmers, aware about its significance.

The volunteers have offered their services to assist the police in enforcement of various measures such as maintaining social distancing, ensuring wearing of masks/gloves and use of sanitizers by farmers, labourers and other stakeholders.

Wheat procurement started in Punjab from April 15. The country is under a lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19.

Title: 35% drop in garbage generation in Doon
Article:
One of the positive effects of the lockdown in Dehradun is being seen in about 35 per cent drop in generation of garbage in the provisional state capital. Stating this, the Sheeshambada solid waste management and recycling plant head of garbage collection and transportation, Rakesh Upadhyay said that various commercial and other activities had ceased in the city due to the lockdown which has resulted in lesser garbage generation.

According to him, these days the quantity of garbage collected by the sanitation workers has reduced by about 30 to 35 per cent. Before the lockdown was imposed an average 330 metric tonnes of garbage was generated per day in the city.

However, after the lockdown was imposed, the quantity has dropped to about 260-270 metric tonnes per day. Upadhyay said, "We are taking all the precautions for the safety of our workers. We are sanitising the garbage collection vehicles before and after collecting the garbage every day. The garbage collection workers are also provided with sufficient Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) kits including sanitisers."

On being asked about the health check up of sanitation workers, Upadhyay said that the regular health check of workers at the plant has been initiated and soon it will be conducted for the workers operating in the city too.

The project head of the Sheeshambada waste management plant MA Saify also confirmed the reduction in the garbage received by the plant. Saify said that the quantity of garbage reaching the plant daily has dropped by about 25 tonnes.

He also stated that there is no shortage of workers in the plant and all the workers are equipped with PPE kit and that the Ramky company is also paying incentives to them.

Moreover, Saify also informed that No Objection Certificate (NOC) for the operation of the Sheeshambada plant has also been renewed by Uttarakhand Environment Protection and Pollution Control Board (UEPPCB).

It is pertinent to mention here that Municipal Corporation of Dehradun (MCD) was reportedly dumping the garbage in the plant without NOC since last year as it had not been renewed by UEPPCB citing several reasons.

Title: Include Sanskrit as compulsorily subject in CBSE Classes 9, 10: Verma
Article:
Rajya Sabha member from the state Chhaya Verma on Thursday demanded that the Union HRD minister make Sanskrit as a compulsory subject in the syllabus for Classes 9 and 10 in schools under the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) board.

Verma, in a letter to the Union minister for human resource development, objected to the recent order of the CBSE board to remove Sanskrit as a compulsory subject in Classes 9 and 10.

“It was because of Sanskrit language, India was a ‘Vishwaguru’ in the past and the dual policy of the Centre will force the people to suffer a lot,” she said.

Before the order, there were five compulsory and one additional subject and students could opt for English, Hindi, Mathematics, Science and Social Science with Sanskrit as an additional subject, Rajya Sabha member said.

There was an option of taking another subject rather than Sanskrit but from now onwards they have to take skill subjects, she said.

The MP demanded that the union minister amend the new provision and make Sanskrit a compulsory subject in the school syllabus.

Title: Dist Youth Congress chief, cop held for bootlegging
Article:
Two policemen wanted in connection with case on the run. DGP directs dist SP to suspended all three and nab the remaining

Mungeli district president of the Youth Congress was arrested along with a police constable in connection with a bootlegging case, police said here on Thursday.

Two police personnel connected in the case are on the run, police said.

Meanwhile, Chhattisgarh director general of police DM Awasthi has instructed the district superintendent of police (SP) to immediately suspend the police personnel and arrest them.

“Rahul Singh was arrested along with police constable Pawan Gandharv from Khudia locality of the district while they were transporting more than 53 liters of liquor in an SUV,” SP Mungeli CD Tondon said while adding that two other constables Lokesh Rajput and Rajendra Kumar Yadav who were in the vehicle, somehow managed to run away from the spot.

Police are searching for them and will arrest them soon, he said.

After the news of Singh’s arrest in connecting bootlegging case, was flashed, he was expelled from the post of the district Youth Congress president, senior state Congress leader Purnchandra Padhi said.

According to the police, the market value of seized liquor is Rs 50,000 and it was being smuggled to Chhattisgarh from neighbouring Dindori district of Madhya Pradesh.

Title: Power Company Board of Directors meet discuss on future plans
Article:
nChhattisgarh state power company board of directors on Thursday held a meeting that was chaired by its chairman Subrat Sahoo to discuss on the distribution, transmission and the holding companies’ future plans.

The meeting discussed the power companies’ structure and its work, filling of vacant posts, construction of high tension sub centres and, expansion of high tension lines among others, a release said.

The meeting further discussed about strengthening the transmission system, it said.

Sahoo also laid emphasis on following the protocol issued for prevention of coronavirus infection.

He said power is linked to the daily need of the people therefore its uninterrupted supply is important.

He also asked officials to remain alert in at the units of the power company.

State additional chief secretary (finance) Amitabh Jain, power distribution-holding company managing director Mohammad Abdul Haque and transmission company MD Ashok Kumar were present at the meeting.

Title: Raipur battles with jaundice
Article:
nThe Chhattisgarh government is faced with a double whammy as it fights with two infections at the same time.

Already struggling to comfort the Covid-19 pandemic, it is now battling an outbreak of jaundice in a number of clusters in Raipur city and neighbouring cities of Bhilai and Durg.

More than 250 people have been infected with the water-borne disease, which is a common reoccurrence in the capital city with start of summer.

This year, the jaundice outbreak has struck in a huge level, putting the state health department and the Raipur Municipal Corporation on its toes.

Meanwhile, an advocate in a letter to the city civic body, citing a verdict of PIL, has pointed out that the Raipur Municipal Corporation (RMC) has to supply potable water in tankers to the affected areas, change of pipelines and other necessary steps to mitigate the water-borne disease.

A release by the state health department said until Wednesday, 116 people with jaundice were admitted to hospitals while 33 people have recovered and discharged.

It further said that 78 people suffering from jaundice are undergoing treatment at the district hospital.

Due to regular camps being held in affected areas more new patients are being detected in the city, the release said.

State Health department is holding camps in affected areas in Bhatagaon, Changorabhata, Mathpurena, Amapara, Daldalseoni, Atari and Mangal Bazaar in the capital city, Khursipar and other neighbhourhoods in Bhilai.

Satnam Panag, chairman of RMC water resources committee said, “The filter bed of the water filtration plant has not been cleaned since it was constructed. The filter bed is muddy and was full of worms.”

In addition, the stream from the stop-dam to the suction pump, due to low water level, and lower flow, polluted water is being sucked into the water filtration plant, Panag said.

“With ineffective filtering in the filter bed, polluted water sipped into the filtration plant.”

He further said that efforts has commenced for re-laying of filter-bed.

“A tender is being floated, leakages have been plugged and the quantity of chlorine in the water has been increased,” he said.

People with more than 18% of bilirubin have been detected but due to timely intervention, the situation is being brought under control, the RMC official said.

On Dangi’s letter to supply potable water in tankers to affected areas, he said, “It will do no good as the water from the filter-plant has to be supplied in tankers.

“If the water is contaminated, the same water will be supplied. Instead, the loopholes in the supply of water are being plugged to tackle it.”

Dr Meera Baghel, district chief medical and health officer said that more than 400 samples have been tested and more than 250 positive cases were detected.

Title: Dhanbad man tests positive, cases rise to 29
Article:
A man in his early twenties tested positive for Covid-19 from Dhanbad on Thursday – the first case from the coal capital of the country, health officials said. With the latest test results out, the number of coronavirus cases in Jharkhand rose to 29 on Thursday, they added.

"He is a resident of Kumardubi in Dhanbad. His samples were collected after he returned from Asansol in West Bengal last week," said Health Secretary Nitin Madan Kulkarni. However, no fresh cases were reported from other parts of the State on Thursday, he added.

Out of the 29 cases reported in Jharkhand so far, 14 are from Ranchi, nine from Bokaro, two from Hazaribag, and one each from Koderma, Giridih, Simdega and Dhanbad, officials said. However, the daily COVID-19 bulletin released by the National Health Mission (NHM) on Thursday did not mention about the latest Coronavirus patient found in Dhanbad.

Despite entering Jharkhand as late as March 31, the virus has infected more than two dozen people since the beginning of April. The Government has identified three major pockets where the virus has infected highest number of people. One of such pockets is Hindpiri in Ranchi, a locality which has alone reported 14 COVID-19 cases so far. The other two pockets are in rural Bokaro, sources said.

The entry of Coronavirus in Dhanbad has spread the lethal virus in seven of 24 districts in Jharkhand. Out of the five divisions here, the virus has infected people only in two divisions, officials said. However, it has entered the most populated cities in the State – Ranchi, Bokaro and now Dhanbad.

By Thursday, the Government collected samples of 3340 suspects in Jharkhand, and 2768 tested negative, said the daily bulletin released by NHM. Around 95,000 people have been put in home quarantine across the State, it added. Besides, nearly 10,000 people have been sent to quarantine centres, the bulletin said.

Nearly 50 per cent cases in Jharkhand are from Ranchi – a cause for concern for the Government. However, the cases have only been reported from one locality and not spread in other parts of the

city.

Title: CM launches mobile App to help migrant labourers
Article:
Chief Minister Hemant Soren today launched a mobile application to help more than eight lakh migrant labourers of Jharkhand stuck in different parts of the country during the nationwide lockdown. Through the App not only the database of the labourers could be made but it will also help the Government to provide them with emergency funds for sustenance.

The CM said during the launch of the App that within the next one week, the State Government will provide financial assistance by identifying the workers of the State, who are stuck in different states of the country. This amount will be transferred directly to the migrant labourers through DBT in their bank account. This amount will be at least Rs 1000. The CM said that the State Government has made an effort to reach the migrant labourers with the Jharkhand Special Assistance Scheme mobile app. Through this App, financial assistance will be provided to migrant laborers.

Soren said that the goal of the government is to provide financial assistance to the migrant labourers of the State within the coming week and day through the App. He said that the government of Jharkhand has been working with limited resources since the early days of Coronavirus spread. In the first phase of the lockdown, a team of officers has been continuously coordinating with other states to provide dry ration etc to the workers of Jharkhand trapped outside the State. The team of officers is continuously working on how to help more and more people.

The CM said that in this hour of Covid-19, the present government has full sympathy with the workers, tribals, dalits, poor, helpless people of Jharkhand. In this hour of crisis, the biggest problem is the labourers and poor people. The government is most concerned about these poor people. The CM said that due to lack of employment in the State, people migrate for employment to other states, due to sudden lockdown, the laborers were stuck where they were. He said that the period of lockdown has been extended, due to which troubles have increased. The entire system of the State government is trying to get maximum assistance in this hour of disaster.

Soren expressed confidence that the mobile App will prove to be a milestone for the help of migrant labourers. The App has been specially created by the team of officials to help the labourers and other State residents trapped in various states of the country during Lockdown 2. He said that the App will also be used by labourers, who do not have smartphones. Even if there is only one smartphone in the group, all the people of the group can still register. It is a very easy and simple one.

On this occasion, Planning cum Finance Minister Rameshwar Oraon, Labour Planning and Training Minister Satyanand Bhokta, Scheduled Tribes Scheduled Castes and Backward Classes Welfare Minister Champai Soren, Health Medical Education and Family Welfare Minister Banna Gupta, Chief Secretary Sukhdev Singh, Additional Chief Secretary Arun Kumar Singh, Principal Secretary to Chief Minister Rajiv Arun Ekka, Principal Secretary AP Singh, Secretary Vinay Choubey, Secretary Sunil Kumar Singh, Press Advisor To Chief Minister Abhishek Prasad, Senior Personal Secretary to CM Sunil Srivastava and other officials were present.

Title: Door-to-door search for suspected cases, focus on fringe areas
Article:
East Singhbhum district administration has embarked on drive to identify Covid-19 suspected cases. Teams formed under three civic bodies of Jamshedpur, Jugsalai and Mango are covering house-to-house to prepare report of people having record of travel history or having symptoms of coronavirus.

The final report will help the district surveillance in monitoring those undergoing quarantine at state centre’s or at homes.

In a massive exercise to identify everybody with travel history either from overseas or domestic, East Singhbhum district administration has also decided to touch all the houses in the district.

With help of the 2011 census, East Singhbhum has identified over 4,76,931 houses in the 11 blocks of the districts (including the urban Jamshedpur-Jugsalai block) and to reach out to each of the houses has mobilised not only the over 1700 sahiyas and anganbari sevikas but also the 1885 booth level officers (entrusted after polling booths during election), panchayat raj institutions and even thana-level community leaders.

We do not want to leave any scope in tracing out an individual who might have come from abroad or from another state or district to East Singhbhum and want to reach each of the houses in urban and rural areas of the district in a limited time span. We have decided to involve everyone entrusted with implementation of government schemes and activities in the exercise and want to complete it within a week,” said East Singhbhum deputy commissioner Ravi Shankar Shukla. Special attention is being given to the elderly, pregnant women and those with co-morbid conditions such as diabetes, hypertension and low immunity.

The team is distributing pamphlets on the measures to be taken to prevent the spread of COVID-19. They would also be informed about quarantine measures for those showing symptoms such as cold, cough and fever.

After identification of the suspected cases, they would be shifted to the isolation ward at the district headquarters hospital.

The administration is taking other steps to deal with the outbreak. A doctor has been made part of the disaster management control room round-the-clock to provide advice, and has also appealed to people not to panic.

This is apart from the screening, testing and quarantine efforts being taken by the administration.

This is an awareness-cum-surveillance drive. They are informed of the symptoms and asked if any resident has them. If there is such a person, we can move them into isolation.

Title: Cong demands relief package for farmers
Article: The Uttarakhand Congress has demanded that the State Government should roll out a relief package to help farmers ravaged by recent hailstones and unseasonal rains. Talking to the media persons, the Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) chief, Pritam Singh said that the farmers of the state have been hit hard by the recent rain and hailstones. He reminded the BJP government of Uttarakhand of the promise the party made to the farmers of the state ahead of the assembly elections of 2017 that their agricultural loans would be waived off and said that it is high time when this promise is fulfilled. He said that the farmers are facing to take their crops to the markets and are forced to sell it at throwaway prices. The PCC president said that every Congress party member is standing with the poor during this period of crisis precipitated by outbreak of novel Coronavirus. “We are making arrangements of distributing cooked meals to the poor by the means of Sonia kitchens and Indira kitchens at many places in the State. The Congress workers are also helping the poor in every possible way,’’ he said.

Title: U’khand babus maintaining distance from offices
Article:
The State secretariat of Uttarakhand continued to wear a deserted look on Thursday even as Central Government- whose guidelines on COVID-19 are being ardently followed by Trivendra Singh Rawat Government - has directed officers above the rank of deputy secretaries and above to start working from their offices.

The State secretariat of Uttarakhand which is the epicentre of all Government activities has almost ceased all operations ever since the lockdown was enforced in the State on March 22 to break the infection cycle of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19).

On the call given by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the State is under second phase of lockdown which would continue till May 3. The Union Government which has earlier allowed its officers work from home during the first phase of lockdown has asked all officers of the rank of deputy secretary and above to attend offices from Thursday. The officers of the joint secretary and above had started attending their offices from Monday (April 13).

This correspondent made a reality check of the secretariat on Thursday and found out that barring few, locks dangled on the doors of the offices of senior bureaucrats.

Though Chief Secretary, Utpal Kumar Singh, was present at his office, the additional chief secretaries (ACS), Radha Raturi and Om Prakash — who heads many important departments — were conspicuous by their absence.

Their offices seemed to have been closed for days. Interestingly enough, the all important secretary, Nitesh Jha was also not present in his office. Jha holds charge of health and home departments, the two most important departments which are playing stellar role in the fight to contain the spread of the COVID-19.

His personal secretary however was present in his office. Similarly secretary in- charge, B K Sant was also not found in his office.

The additional secretary of medical health and Mission Director (MD) of National Health Mission (NHM) was also not present in his office.

These days this officer works from his office located at state health directorate.

It was found that in the sprawling Vishwakarma building of the secretariat, the secretary (in-charge), Bhupal Singh Manral was the only senior officer who was

present in his office.

While on one hand, the senior officers of Uttarakhand spearheading different departments are continuing to maintain distance from their workplaces on the other hand their counterparts in Centre and other States have started working from offices.

Interestingly the state government has directed the administration to prepare work plan for the partial relaxations which the Government intends to provide in the districts where the cases of COVID-19 have not been reported. Similarly there is a big challenge before the government to bring the economy back on track after the lockdown is lifted.

The problems of farmers, stranded migrants and the issue of ready to be harvested Rabi crops also require deft handling and immediate decisions.

It is clear that these things cannot be done from a closed secretariat. Senior journalist, Rajendra Joshi said, “The senior officers should come to their offices so that things don’t become messy when the lockdown opens.

Moreover, secretariat is not a place which can get crowded by general public.’’

Title: Authorities continue psychological counselling in relief camps
Article:
Medical counsellors and psychiatrists are providing regular counselling for people from other districts and States and currently living in relief camps of Dehradun district. Also, the suspected COVID-19 patients besides the positive tested patients in isolation are also being provided counselling by the administration.

Several people including labourers and daily wagers who got stuck in the city after the implementation of lockdown are sheltered in about 22 relief camps by the district administration.

To keep them motivated during the lockdown period, daily psychological counselling sessions are being provided to all. According to the chief medical superintendent of State Mental Health Institute, Selaqui, Dr Abhishek Gupta," We received directions from the State administration to form a team of medical counsellors and psychiatrists in order to carry out regular psychological counselling of the people staying in the relief camps of Dehradun." Most of the people want to return to their homes so the team asks them to be patient, support the administration and remain positive besides maintaining their hygiene and social distancing in the camps.” He further informed that the counselling was commenced from April 1 and those in relief camps are being counselled every day.

Talking about the counselling of suspected patients in quarantine and positive patients in isolation in the hospital, Dr Gupta said that these patients are also being provided counselling.

He added that once a patient or person is first counselled, follow up counselling is also being carried out, especially through phones or online in case of infected patients, to know the status of their mental conditions.

The Dehradun Chief Development Officer (CDO) Nikita Khandelwal said that the two types of counselling are being carried out. "In the relief camps, psychological counselling is being provided besides the means of entertainment like television, board games and sometimes a Yoga teacher teaches Yoga,” informed Khandelwal.

She further informed surveillance and counselling is being done for suspected patients in quarantine. The doctors call the patients and ask them about their health or any issues they might have which helps to understand the mental condition of patients, added the CDO.

Title: Covid-19: Unlocking a battery of heinous crimes
Article:
As the nation heads towards an extended lockdown till May 3, boredom is the least of our issues. While the pandemic has lead to an unprecedented scenario which entails the release of prisoners on bail or parole, it has also unearthed a surge in offences especially against women and children. The irksome quarantine has acted like a trigger for the depraved minds creating a grim picture of violence within the four walls. “Violence is not confined to the battlefield”, these words of the UN secretary general Antonio Guterres clearly depict the tragic status quo.

Up to one billion children aged between 2 to 17 years, have experienced physical, sexual or emotional violence or neglect in the past year as per global estimation. Childline helpline 1098- a 24x7 free, emergency phone service for children in need of help, which usually receives two lakh calls in a week has witnessed an enormous increase since March 24- the day when the lockdown was first imposed.

The data of Women and Child Development Ministry represents majority of the callers claiming abuse and the others highlighting issues like stress, physical health, child labour, missing cases, homeless and sickness and queries on coronavirus among others. Violence against children includes all forms of violence against people aged below 18 years, whether perpetrated by parents, caregivers, peers, partners or strangers.

It is not only the children but also the mothers or women in a more exhaustive sense, who face similar atrocities. Domestic violence being the leading crime against women has shown no drop in these testing times. On the contrary the complaints of sexual, physical and mental harassment have also accelerated. A crime like this which usually gets unreported due to various social challenges faced by the individual has been converted to 100 complaints via emails and over 300 complaints related to various offences during the last two weeks.

According to UN Women, a United Nations entity working for the empowerment of women, globally 243 million girls and women aged 15-49 years have been subjected to physical violence perpetuated by a known persons in the past 12 months.

The confinement has fostered an environment of tension making such victims feel more vulnerable, as they are unable to leave their houses. The inaccessibility to various support networks has made it even worse for the children or women to seek help or escape.

It is the need of the hour for the authorities to step in by taking proactive measures to protect the dignity of children and women - their fundamental right as a facet of Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, while also ensuring their safety. The judiciary, Government and its law enforcement agencies must mobilise to ensure that such acts of violence are given utmost priority with no impunity to the culprit.

The measures which can be adopted should include enhanced toll free hotlines round the clock, free text message services, remote psychological support, child care cash transfers, other online tools and networks to amplify social support system and a comprehensive mechanism to reach the victims with no access to mobile phones or internet.

It is not only a moral obligation but also a constitutional duty of the government to safeguard the rights and provide protection against violence to every citizen. In consonance with the objectives enshrined in the directive principles of our State policy it is the primary duty of the State to raise the level of nutrition, render food security and bring improvement in public health which would in turn assist in care of the destitute women and children. The crimes during lockdown are not limited to just a few, as novel misdemeanours and ghastly acts have taken the centre stage.

While some of the essential services distributors and retailers are defrauding the consumers even after constant warnings by the authorities, some patients infected with the virus are attacking the doctors and nurses treating them.

Even some of the common masses after defying the lockdown are acting in contempt of the police (including the latest diabolical incident of chopping the hand of the Punjab police personnel), there is an increment in the number of cyber crimes with the sale of counterfeit health care products- masks, sanitisers and substandard personal protective equipments being the most promising venture. While criminals have been swift to seize opportunities to exploit the crisis by adapting their modus operandi or diversifying the criminal activities, it is our window of opportunity to act as vigilant community watchdogs to debunk such offences in every possible way. Stay positive, stay civilised and remain quarantined.

(The author is a practising lawyer in the High Court of Delhi. Views expressed are personal)

Title: Six patients recover from COVID-19 discharged from AIIMS Raipur
Article:
Six more coronavirus (COVID-19) patients were on Thursday discharged from the AIIMS, Raipur after they recovered from the viral infection.

With this, the total number of active cases in Chhattisgarh now stands at 10, officials said.

“The six patients, including two women, hailing from Katghora town of the state’s Korba district, were discharged after two consecutive tests came out negative for the infection,” a public relations official of the AIIMS said.

Now, 10 patients are undergoing treatment at AIIMS, the official said.

Katghora, located around 200 km from the state capital Raipur, has emerged as the COVID-19 contamination spot in the state with 24 confirmed cases reported there until now.

So far by Thursday evening 5,519 sample for COVID-19 testing were carried out across Chhattisgarh, out of which reports of 5,168 were found negative.

The remaining 318 samples are under testing process, health department officials said.

According to health officials, 69,144 people across Chhattisgarh are currently in home quarantine and 26,411 people have successfully completed home quarantine period.

Meanwhile, Chhattisgarh health secretary Niharika Barik Singh has asked health department officials to formulate a strategy for undertaking pool sampling process in the state.

Pool sampling process has been suggested by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR).

Title: Naxal killed in encounter in Bijapur
Article:
A Maoist rebel was killed in a gun-battle with the security forces on Thursday in the insurgency-affected Bijapur district, police said.

The skirmish took place in the forests under the Mirtur police station area adjoining Dantewada district, when a joint team of the security forces was out on a counter-insurgency operation, inspector general of police (Bastar range) Sundarraj P said.

Personnel belonging to the District Reserve Guard (DRG) and the Special Task Force (STF) had launched the operation from Dantewada inside the jungles of Dantewada-Bijapur districts border, he said.

When the patrolling team was cordoning off a forest in Mirtur area, located around 450 km away from the capital Raipur, and an exchange of fire broke out between the two sides, he said.

After the guns fell silent, the body of a male rebel was recovered from the spot, he said.

Further details are awaited as the search operation was still underway in the area, he added.

Title: Paddy difference amount to farmers soon: Congress
Article:
nThe state Congress on Thursday said a budgetary provision for the difference in the minimum support price (MSP) of paddy has already been made by the state government and it will soon be paid to the farmers.

Replying to a demand raised by the BJP in this regard, state Congress general secretary and chairman of the communication wing Shailesh Nitin Trivedi said the state government was sensitive to the need of the farmers in this crucial time and soon the balance amount will be paid to them.

Notable, chief minister Bhupesh Baghel had announced to pay Rs 2,500 per quintal to farmers for paddy procured by the state government.

Trivedi further said that due to some bindings as per the Centre’s instructions, the state government had procured paddy from farmers in the state at the MSP prescribed by the Centre—the MSP for the common grade paddy at Rs 1,815 per quintal and for grade A crop at Rs 1,835.

“As the state government had promised that the paddy would be procured from the farmers at the rate of Rs 2,500 per quintal.

“But by doing so the Centre, due to its policy decision, was unable to take the surplus rice from the state in the central pool under the National Food Security Act, through the Food Corporation of India,” he said.

So keeping in view of the technical difficulty, the state government will now disburse the balance amount of Rs 685 per quintal in the bank accounts of the farmers in the state as the Congress government in the state had promised, he said.

Title: State police distributes food amongst 8,99,465 persons
Article:
State police has also extended a helping hand to the needy serving them food at the time of lockdown. So far the police have distributed food amongst 8,99,465 persons ever since the community kitchen was started across nearly 400 police stations in the 24 districts of the state on March 28. Dhanbad police tops the list in terms of distribution of foods by reaching out to 1.8 lakh (1,80,999) persons with two times (afternoon and evening) meals.

This is followed by East Singhbhum (Jamshedpur) police, which is distributing foods has distributed food amongst 1.3 lakh (1,30,030) persons while capital Ranchi is in the third position distributing foods amongst 1.2 lakh needy persons (1,20,224).

Title: Marandi missive to CM over migrant labourers’ woes
Article:
Amid reports of migrant workers walking down to their villages due to lockdown in the Country BJP legislative party leader Babulal Marandi has urged the State Government to help them reach their villages. The BJP legislative party leader said that he is pained seeing thousands of migrant labourers stranded in various parts of cities.

“I am pained at seeing thousands of migrant labourers from the State standard at different parts of country. These people are facing difficult times as they neither have food nor accommodation. They are poor people and it is our duty to help them," said Marandi.

He further said, “When so many people from the State are stranded at different parts of country we can send aircrafts to get them back. Everyone wants to stay with their families during such time of crisis. We must help them and I urged the State government to take a quick action in this connection."

The senior BJP leader in this connection has written a letter to Chief Minister Hemant Soren and State Labour resource Minister Satyanand Bhokta to airlift labourers. Marandi has also urged the State government to send different teams of senior government officials to different parts of country where migrant labourers are stranded. According to Marandi labourers from the State go to Surat, Delhi, Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Pune, Bangalore, Jaipur, Gaziabad and other cities in search of bread and butter.

The Jharkhand government has set up control rooms, through which these labourers’ contact tracing is being done. The state government, along with several NGOs and civil societies, has tried to reach out to these labourers. Moreover public representatives such as MPs, MLAs are also receiving phone calls from migrant labourers. Marandi's letter to Chief Minister assumes importance as recently CPI-ML MLA from Bagodar Vinod Singh has tried to draw the attention of State government towards labourers woe’s. Singh targeting MPs from Bihar and Jharkhand has said that these two states have 54 MPs, but none of them have taken any initiative to help out migrant labourers. Singh giving reference from a newspaper report has highlighted that a MP from Andhra Pradesh has helped 1000 labourers in reaching homes from Varanasi.

As Prime Minister Narendra Modi has extended the 21-day lockdown upto May 3 these migrant labourers problem is going to escalate in coming days. Sources said that as many as 75 per cent of labourers have already lost one to three weeks of work. The loss of income is proving to be catastrophic on several fronts. Most of the migrant labourers and daily wage earners fear they will run out of food before the end of lockdown on May 3. Moreover many also worry that they will not be able to find work once the lockdown ends. The Centre and State government has tried to lessen the pains of the migrants during the pandemic.

Title: Trading activity to begin soon in J'khand: Oraon
Article:
The State Finance Minister, Rameshwar Oraon on Thursday assured a delegation of Federation of Jharkhand Chambers of Commerce and Industries (FJCCI) that trading activity will start soon in the State according to the guidelines of Ministry of Home Affairs after April, 20.

FJCCI held a meeting with the Finance Minister to discuss on the several issues and to kick start trading activity in the State.

During the meeting, the delegation demanded that the Government should waive the fixed electricity charge of the industries for the entire duration of the lockdown and also urged the Government's permission to streamline the transportation of goods in the State for movement of material to the industries starting from April 21.

FJCCI, General Secretary, Dhiraj Taneja said that because of shutting down the industry for so many days, there will be problem in starting of the units. It was also suggested that the State Government, through its own effort, should arrange to provide loans to the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) of the State by bringing international funding," he added.

Oraon assured to consider the matter seriously and also sought the necessary draft from the Chamber. The delegation also said that initiative should be taken to free MSMEs and SMEs for the next 3 or 5 years from the constraint of small unnecessary compliance, as there are many unnecessary complaints from which the Government does not get any special revenue but due to this, entrepreneurs face many troubles.
